qas.question: What did the muzzle flashes of the firearms used by the infantry reveal?
Along with speed of the modern jet, what else limits target opportunities?
Heavier artillery systems were typically used for what?

context: Although the firearms used by the infantry, particularly machine guns, can be used to engage low altitude air targets, on occasion with notable success, their effectiveness is generally limited and the muzzle flashes reveal <a0_0>infantry positions<a0_0/>. Speed and <a1_0>altitude<a1_0/> of modern jet aircraft limit target opportunities, and critical systems may be armored in aircraft designed for the ground attack role. Adaptations of the standard autocannon, originally intended for air-to-ground use, and heavier artillery systems were commonly used for <a2_0>most anti-aircraft gunnery<a2_0/>, starting with standard pieces on new mountings, and evolving to specially designed guns with much higher performance prior to World War II.
